t: Mark 12
The Parable of the Tenants

Jesus*p then began to speak to them in parables: “A*r man*r planted*r a*r vineyard.*r He*r put*r a*r wall*r around*r it,*r dug*r a*r pit*r for*r the*r winepress*r and*r built*r a*r watchtower.*r Then*r he*r rented*r the*r vineyard*r to*r some*r farmers*r and*r moved*r to*r another*r place.*r
At*r harvest*r time*r he*r sent*r a*r servant*r to*r the*r tenants*r to*r collect*r from*r them*r some*r of*r the*r fruit*r of*r the*r vineyard.*r
But*r they*r seized*r him,*r beat*r him*r and*r sent*r him*r away*r empty-handed.*r
Then*r he*r sent*r another*r servant*r to*r them;*r they*r struck*r this*r man*r on*r the*r head*r and*r treated*r him*r shamefully.*r
He*r sent*r still*r another,*r and*r that*r one*r they*r killed.*r He*r sent*r many*r others;*r some*r of*r them*r they*r beat,*r others*r they*r killed.*r
“He*rp had*r one*r left*r to*r send,*r a*r son,*r whom*r he*r loved.*r He*r sent*r him*r last*r of*r all,*r saying,*r ‘They*r will*r respect*r my*r son.’*r
“But*rp the*r tenants*r said*r to*r one*r another,*r ‘This*r is*r the*r heir.*r Come,*r let’s*r kill*r him,*r and*r the*r inheritance*r will*r be*r ours.’*r
So*r they*r took*r him*r and*r killed*r him,*r and*r threw*r him*r out*r of*r the*r vineyard.*r
“What*rp then*r will*r the*r owner*r of*r the*r vineyard*r do?*r He*r will*r come*r and*r kill*r those*r tenants*r and*r give*r the*r vineyard*r to*r others.*r
Haven’t*r you*r read*r this*r passage*r of*r Scripture:*r “ ‘The*rpn stone*r the*r builders*r rejected*r has*rld become*r the*r cornerstone;*r
the*rln Lord*r has*r done*r this,*r and*rld it*r is*r marvelous*r in*r our*r eyes’?”*r

Then*p the chief priests, the teachers of the law and the elders looked for a way to arrest him because they knew he had spoken the parable against them. But they were afraid of the crowd; so they left him and went away.
Paying the Imperial Tax to Caesar
Later*p they sent some of the Pharisees and Herodians to Jesus to catch him in his words.

They came to him and said, “Teacher, we know that you are a man of integrity. You aren’t swayed by others, because you pay no attention to who they are; but you teach the way of God in accordance with the truth. Is it right to pay the imperial tax to Caesar or not?
Should we pay or shouldn’t we?” But*p Jesus knew their hypocrisy. “Why*r are*r you*r trying*r to*r trap*r me?”*r he asked. “Bring*r me*r a*r denarius*r and*r let*r me*r look*r at*r it.”*r
They brought the coin, and he asked them, “Whose*r image*r is*r this?*r And*r whose*r inscription?”*r “Caesar’s,”*p they replied.
Then*p Jesus said to them, “Give*r back*r to*r Caesar*r what*r is*r Caesar’s*r and*r to*r God*r what*r is*r God’s.”*r And*p they were amazed at him.
Marriage at the Resurrection
Then*p the Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to him with a question.
“Teacher,” they said, “Moses wrote for us that if a man’s brother dies and leaves a wife but no children, the man must marry the widow and raise up offspring for his brother.
Now there were seven brothers. The first one married and died without leaving any children.
The second one married the widow, but he also died, leaving no child. It was the same with the third.
In fact, none of the seven left any children. Last of all, the woman died too.
At the resurrection whose wife will she be, since the seven were married to her?”
Jesus*p replied, “Are*r you*r not*r in*r error*r because*r you*r do*r not*r know*r the*r Scriptures*r or*r the*r power*r of*r God?*r
When*r the*r dead*r rise,*r they*r will*r neither*r marry*r nor*r be*r given*r in*r marriage;*r they*r will*r be*r like*r the*r angels*r in*r heaven.*r

Now*r about*r the*r dead*r rising—have*r you*r not*r read*r in*r the*r Book*r of*r Moses,*r in*r the*r account*r of*r the*r burning*r bush,*r how*r God*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘I*r am*r the*r God*r of*r Abraham,*r the*r God*r of*r Isaac,*r and*r the*r God*r of*r Jacob’?*r
He*r is*r not*r the*r God*r of*r the*r dead,*r but*r of*r the*r living.*r You*r are*r badly*r mistaken!”*r
The Greatest Commandment
One*p of the teachers of the law came and heard them debating. Noticing that Jesus had given them a good answer, he asked him, “Of all the commandments, which is the most important?”
“The*rp most*r important*r one,”*r answered Jesus, “is*r this:*r ‘Hear,*r O*r Israel:*r The*r Lord*r our*r God,*r the*r Lord*r is*r one.*r
Love*r the*r Lord*r your*r God*r with*r all*r your*r heart*r and*r with*r all*r your*r soul*r and*r with*r all*r your*r mind*r and*r with*r all*r your*r strength.’*r
The*r second*r is*r this:*r ‘Love*r your*r neighbor*r as*r yourself.’*r There*r is*r no*r commandment*r greater*r than*r these.”*r
“Well*p said, teacher,” the man replied. “You are right in saying that God is one and there is no other but him.
To love him with all your heart, with all your understanding and with all your strength, and to love your neighbor as yourself is more important than all burnt offerings and sacrifices.”
When*p Jesus saw that he had answered wisely, he said to him, “You*r are*r not*r far*r from*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God.”*r And from then on no one dared ask him any more questions.
Whose Son Is the Messiah?
While*p Jesus was teaching in the temple courts, he asked, “Why*r do*r the*r teachers*r of*r the*r law*r say*r that*r the*r Messiah*r is*r the*r son*r of*r David?*r

David*r himself,*r speaking*r by*r the*r Holy*r Spirit,*r declared:*r “ ‘The*rpn Lord*r said*r to*r my*r Lord:*r “Sit*rld at*r my*r right*r hand*r until*rln I*r put*r your*r enemies*r under*rld your*r feet.” ’*r
David*rp himself*r calls*r him*r ‘Lord.’*r How*r then*r can*r he*r be*r his*r son?”*r The*p large crowd listened to him with delight.
Warning Against the Teachers of the Law

As*p he taught, Jesus said, “Watch*r out*r for*r the*r teachers*r of*r the*r law.*r They*r like*r to*r walk*r around*r in*r flowing*r robes*r and*r be*r greeted*r with*r respect*r in*r the*r marketplaces,*r
and*r have*r the*r most*r important*r seats*r in*r the*r synagogues*r and*r the*r places*r of*r honor*r at*r banquets.*r
They*r devour*r widows’*r houses*r and*r for*r a*r show*r make*r lengthy*r prayers.*r These*r men*r will*r be*r punished*r most*r severely.”*r
The Widow’s Offering
Jesus*p sat down opposite the place where the offerings were put and watched the crowd putting their money into the temple treasury. Many rich people threw in large amounts.
But a poor widow came and put in two very small copper coins, worth only a few cents.
Calling*p his disciples to him, Jesus said, “Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r this*r poor*r widow*r has*r put*r more*r into*r the*r treasury*r than*r all*r the*r others.*r
They*r all*r gave*r out*r of*r their*r wealth;*r but*r she,*r out*r of*r her*r poverty,*r put*r in*r everything—all*r she*r had*r to*r live*r on.”*r
